p.s: Runner beans , also known as string beans , are long , slender bean pods that are popular in many vegetable gardens .
Throughout the growing season , runner beans will ripen and be ready for you to eat .
With simple harvesting techniques and kitchen prep , you can enjoy fresh vegetables at any time !

item.s: Start picking your beans in the middle of summer .
Beans planted in the spring can be harvested in the later summer months , typically August and September in the Northern hemisphere .
Keep track of when you planted your beans to determine the best time to start your harvest .
Runner beans take about 3 months to fully develop from seeds .
Harvest the pods when they are long .
Look for bean pods that still have a smooth texture .
If you can see the beans through the outer pod , the beans are past their prime and may have a tough , stringy texture when you eat them .
Larger bean pods may look impressive , but they ’ll have a rougher and less desirable texture .
Pull the bean pod off the stems by hand .
Grab the bean where it connects to the stem with your thumb and index finger .
Hold the stem with your other hand and gently pull the bean off .
Keep the beans you pick in a bag or bucket so you do n’t have to carry them .
Check your plant every 2 days for ripe beans .
Runner beans can grow quickly and they will grow multiple times throughout the growing season .
Keep checking your plant until the first frost .
If you have too many beans , ask your neighbors to see if they want to pick any for themselves .
Leave some of the pods on your plant to dry .
Let the seed pods turn a pale straw-color until early autumn .
Once the seeds rattle inside the pods , remove them from the plants and bring them inside .
Remove the beans from the pods and let them dry on a tray until they feel light and hollow .
Store the beans in mason jars in a cool , dark place .
When you want to eat the beans , soak them in cool water for 8 hours before you cook them .

list.item:
Separate the good beans from bad beans .
Get rid of any beans that are soft to the touch or yellowing .
Also dispose of any pods where you can see the beans through the skin .
Only keep beans that are smooth , firm , and a solid green color .

Keep fresh beans in the fridge for 1 week .
Put your beans in an airtight container in the vegetable drawer of your refrigerator .
Make sure they are dry before you store them or else they could develop mold .

item.s: Freeze the beans for up to 1 year .
Put your beans in a freezer-safe bag and squeeze all the air out from it .
Seal the bag and use a marker to label them with the date so you know how long you ’ve had them .
Cut the ends off the beans .
Rinse your beans thoroughly with water and pat them dry .
Use a chef ’s knife to remove the tips from each side of the bean .
Cut off and throw away the pieces when you ’re finished .
Remove the strings from the sides of the beans with a vegetable peeler .
Hold the bean so the inside edge faces up .
Start your vegetable peeler on one end of the bean , and pull it down the length of the bean where it looks like there ’s a seam .
Flip the bean over and remove the string from the other side .
If you leave the string on , it will be tough to chew when you eat them .
Fresh runner beans can be stored in the freezer for up to 8 months .
Cook the beans in boiling water for 3-4 minutes .
Drop the beans into water over medium heat .
After 3-4 minutes , the beans should be bright green and tender .
Use your knife to see if the beans cut apart easily .
Salt your water before you add the beans so they can absorb the flavor .

list.item: Runner beans can be eaten fresh or cooked .
